subject: Re: [junit] How to run a parametrized Junit test in Eclipse
msgSnippet: Pradeep, I successfully used JUnit 4.1 in Eclipse 3.1.2, here s how: 1. Download JUnit (you ve already done that). 2. Add the downloaded JUnit.jar to your
messageBody:
Pradeep,

I successfully used JUnit 4.1 in Eclipse 3.1.2, here's how:

1. Download JUnit (you've already done that).
2. Add the downloaded JUnit.jar to your project's classpath and NOT the one that comes with Eclipse.
3. Add the following method to each of your test classes:
public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
return new JUnit4TestAdapter(MyTestClassName.class);
}
4. Now you should be able to run it as a JUnit test.

Alternatively, switch to Eclipse 3.2 as David recommended and you do not need to perform step 3.

Tutorials and Articles
http://schuchert.wikispaces.com/



----- Original Message ----
From: David Saff <saff@...>
To: pradeep yadav <pradeep_3diitr@...>; junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 6, 2006 8:00:30 AM
Subject: Re: [junit] How to run a parametrized Junit test in Eclipse


One more thought: please always respond to messages on the list, not
directly to the poster.

David Saff

pradeep yadav wrote:
> Hi David,
>
> Thanks for replying.
>
> Sorry I got confused at that time. It's not a parametrized test, but
> yes it worked on command line (which I have mentioned in earlier
> mail). But when I run through Eclipse (v 3.1.2) it doesn't work.
> getName() function simply returns Name of the Employee. One thing -
> with Junit v4p.1 we don't have to specify function name prefixed with
> 'test' I guess.
>
> Regards,
>
> Pradee
>
> */David Saff <saff@...>/* wrote:
>
> Pradeep,
>
> Which version of Eclipse are you using? The following should work in
> Eclipse 3.2 without change.
>
> Two more questions, if I may:
>
> 1) This doesn't look like a parameterized test case to me. Does it
> to you?
> 2) What does the testName field do?
>
> Thanks, and good luck,
>
> David Saff
>
> pradeep_3diitr wrote:
> > I am using Junit 4.1 with new style of writing Tests using @Test
> > annotations etc.
> >
> > I have written following class --> EmployeeTest to Test Employee
> > class.
> >
> > Following is the portion of EmployeeTest. java -->
> >
> > import org.junit.Test;
> > import org.junit.runner. RunWith;
> > import org.junit.runners. Parameterized;
> > import org.junit.runners. Parameterized. Parameters;
> > import org.junit.Assert;
> > import org.junit.Before;
> > import org.junit.After;
> > import org.junit.Ignore;
> >
> > import org.junit.runner. Result;
> >
> > import java.util.LinkedLis t;
> > import java.util.Iterator;
> >
> > public class EmployeeTest
> > {
> > private Employee satendra;
> > private Employee pradeep;
> > private Employee sriram;
> > String testName;
> > private Result res;
> >
> > @Before
> > public void setUp()
> > {
> > res = new Result();
> > satendra = new Employee("Satendra
> > Diwedi",30,50000, null);
> > pradeep = new Employee("Pradeep
> > Yadav",26,30000, satendra) ;
> > sriram = new Employee("Sriram
> > Sethumadhavan" ,26,35000, satendra) ;
> > }
> >
> > @Test
> > public void getName()
> > {
> > testName = "getName";
> > Assert.assertEquals ("Satendra
> > Diwedi",satendra. getName() );
> > Assert.assertEquals ("Pradeep Yadav",pradeep. getName
> > ());
> > }
> > }
> >
> > Now my problem is that this class - EmployeeTest has not inherited
> > TestCase class. As such Eclipse doesn't recognize it as a JUnit
> > Test. It says --> "No Test Found" when I try it running as a Junit
> > Test.
> >
> > What the solution to this problem?
> >
> > From Command Line run using --> java org.junit.runner. JUnitCore
> > EmployeeTest - it runs fine.
> >
> > Regards,
> >
> > Pradeep
